TextView.android:text: What to eat during the THIRD trimester

As your bump gets bigger, you'll probably need to eat a little more to make sure you're getting enough energy. Try our delicious ideas to make sure you and your baby are getting all the nutrition you need. n your third trimester (28 weeks-plus), vitamin C, fibre, vitamin K and thiamine (vitamin B1) are especially important. You'll be getting enough of these nutrients if you have a varied, healthy diet. Remember that you need an extra 200 calories a day at this stage of your pregnancy.

Tuck in to fresh fruit. It's bursting with vitamin C, as well as fibre. Slice fruit such as kiwis, strawberries, melon and papaya, and take to work for a quick snack. Or pop a piece of fruit in your bag if time's short. Vitamin C helps your body to absorb iron from food and keeps your immune system in shape. It also plays a part in helping the placenta to develop and work properly.

Use canned kidney, borlotti, cannellini or black-eyed beans to make a spicy chilli that's full of thiamine, iron and fibre. Add fresh tomatoes and peppers for vitamin C. Constipation is a common problem at this stage. So drink lots of water, decaffeinated drinks, juices or soups, and eat plenty of fibre-rich foods. Take gentle exercise such as walking and swimming, too.

A homemade lean bacon and tomato sandwich should hit the spot. Grill two rashers of unsmoked, thin-sliced bacon, and make a sandwich with fresh granary bread and sliced, vine-ripened tomatoes.Full of vitamin C and thiamine, and will give you the energy you need in these final few weeks of pregnancy.
Have thiamine-packed baked beans on wholemeal or seeded toast. The fibre in this snack will help to keep constipation at bay and steady your energy levels throughout the day.
Choose thin slices of lean ham for a thiamine boost, and add to a vitamin-rich salad of tomatoes, radishes, sweetcorn and lettuce. Thiamine helps to release energy from the food that you eat.

Add cooked lentils to dhals, soups, stews and salads for a tasty thiamine and fibre boost. If you're buying a soup, check that it's low in salt, and make sure that you heat it through thoroughly before eating.

If snacking on seeds and nuts isn't your thing, thiamine-packed sunflower seeds, and nuts such as walnuts and hazelnuts, are added to some breads, breakfast cereals and cereal bars. They also contain essential omega-3 fats. When choosing muesli, check that it has no added sugar, and add a handful of fresh fruit such as raspberries or kiwi fruit for extra vitamin C.

Love them or hate them, the humble brussels sprout is a vitamin C and vitamin K-rich vegetable. Steam or microwave until just cooked as a side-dish, or slice and use in stir-fries with spring onions, ginger and garlic. Don't overcook vegetables, as it destroys some of the nutrients. Steam or microwave them to retain the goodness, and to prevent the vitamins from leaching out into the water.
